content:
The Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act of 2016 includes provisions for water quality financing, technical and management assistance, state water pollution control revolving funds, and alternative water source grants. The Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act of 2016 includes provisions for alternative water source projects, sewer overflow control grants, and technical assistance under Title I - Water Quality Financing. The Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act of 2016 includes provisions for alternative water source projects, sewer overflow control grants, and technical assistance for rural, small, and tribal municipalities to plan, develop, and finance eligible projects. The Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act of 2016 aims to assist rural, small, and tribal municipalities in improving water quality and complying with regulations through funding and information dissemination. Amendments are made to authorize appropriations for these initiatives. Amendments to section 1254(u) authorize appropriations not to exceed $100,000,000 for fiscal years 2017 through 2021 for specific water quality initiatives. At least 20 percent of the funds must be used for a particular subsection. SEC. 102. STATE MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1991 through 2016 and $300,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2017 through 2021. Technical amendment made to section 106(e).

SEC. 103. WATERSHED PILOT PROJECTS. Authorization of appropriations for $120,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2017 through 2021 for watershed pilot projects. SEC. 104. NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS amended to allocate $200,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2017 through 2021. Subtitle B focuses on State Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds, specifically addressing CAPITALIZATION GRANT AGREEMENTS. SEC. 111 amends Section 602(b) to require states to use at least 15 percent of capitalization grants for assisting small municipalities meeting affordability criteria. Section 603(d) (33 U.S.C. 1383(d)) is amended to provide grants to owners and operators of treatment works serving populations of 10,000 or fewer for technical and planning assistance, financial management, user fee analysis, and other activities to improve wastewater treatment plant management. The total amount of grants provided by the State under this paragraph for a fiscal year may not exceed one percent of the total assistance provided by the State. The State provides grants to owners and operators of treatment works for energy and water conservation assessments and projects. The total amount of grants provided by the State may not exceed one percent of the total assistance provided in the preceding fiscal year. The State may provide grants to treatment works for energy and water conservation assessments and projects, not exceeding 1% of the total assistance provided in the previous fiscal year. Additionally, the State may allocate funds from the capitalization grants under this title, with the amount being the greater of 1% of the total assistance or 2% of the total grants received in the previous fiscal year. SEC. 113. STATE PLANNING ASSISTANCE. Amends Section 604(b) to increase the percentage from 1% to 2%.

SEC. 114. INTENDED USE PLAN. Integrated Priority List amendment requires States to establish a list of projects for water pollution control funding based on priority order and methodology. Nonpoint sources of pollution can also be included in the list. Each State must establish a methodology for developing a priority list of projects for water pollution control funding, giving priority to projects that achieve the greatest water quality improvement. This includes considering the requirements of section 602(b)(5) and whether the improvements would occur without intervention. The State must prioritize projects for water pollution control funding based on their potential for water quality improvement. Factors to consider include information from state reports, planning processes, and addressing water quality impairments associated with treatment works. The State prioritizes projects for water pollution control funding based on potential water quality improvement, considering factors like state reports, planning processes, and addressing impairments associated with treatment works. Nonpoint sources of pollution on the priority list should also consider cumulative water quality improvements from related projects or activities. The State prioritizes projects for water pollution control funding based on potential water quality improvement, considering factors like state reports, planning processes, and addressing impairments associated with treatment works. Nonpoint sources of pollution on the priority list should also consider cumulative water quality improvements from related projects or activities. Activities carried out pursuant to the listing of categories or subcategories can use existing methodologies if they meet the requirements. Each State shall annually prepare and publish its priority list developed under section 603(g). Before completion of a priority list based on a methodology established under section 603(g) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, a State must explain any changes in project funding order. SEC. 115. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. The Administrator will help States establish simplified procedures for treatment works to receive assistance under this title. A manual will be published to aid treatment works in obtaining assistance. SEC. 116. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Title VI is amended to include authorization of appropriations. "Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2017 to 2021 totaling $20 billion. Pilot program for alternative water source projects under Title II." SEC. 201 amends selection process, committee resolution procedure, definitions, and authorization of appropriations for alternative water source projects. SEC. 202 addresses sewer overflow control grants. Section 221 (33 U.S.C. 1301) is amended to provide grants for planning, design, and construction of treatment works for municipal sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects. Grants can be given to states for distribution to municipalities or directly to municipalities for these purposes. Section 221 (33 U.S.C. 1301) is amended to provide grants for planning, design, and construction of treatment works for municipal sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects. Grants can be given to states for distribution to municipalities or directly to municipalities for these purposes. Administrative requirements and authorization of appropriations are specified, with $500,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2021. The Administrator shall allocate $500,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2021 for projects related to intercepting, controlling, and treating sewer overflows and stormwater. At least 20 percent of the grants must be used for green infrastructure and environmentally innovative activities. The Administrator will allocate funds for grants to municipalities and municipal entities in fiscal year 2017, and to States in fiscal year 2018 and beyond, for sewer overflow and stormwater projects based on established criteria and formulas. The Administrator will allocate funds for sewer overflow and stormwater projects based on established criteria and formulas, including controls identified in surveys.
